item.title: GOP Tax Chair Says SALT Lawmakers Should Take $30,000 Limit
item.description: The chair of the House’s tax-writing panel said the $30,000 limit his committee put on the state and local tax deduction is “fair” and lawmakers from high-tax states should accept it.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: Representative Jason Smith

item.title: US-China Trade Clash Risks Making Europe Dumping Ground for Cheap Goods
item.description: China’s widening trade surplus with the European Union is fueling fresh concerns that the 27-nation bloc risks becoming a dumping ground for cheap goods in the volatile tariff confrontation between Washington and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Port of Barcelona.

item.title: Trump’s Pledge to Lift Syrian Sanctions Faces a Complex Road
item.description: US President Donald Trump says he’s ready to ease sanctions on Syria. He won’t be able to do it quickly.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: Buildings destroyed during the war in Harasta, on the outskirts of Damascus, Syria. Photographer: David Lombeida/Bloomberg

item.title: Qatar’s Wealth Fund Plans $500 Billion US Push Over Next Decade
item.description: During his first 15 years at Qatar Investment Authority, Mohammed Al Sowaidi helped establish its US presence and scout opportunities. Now, as head of the $524 billion state-backed entity, he’s pledging to invest an amount nearly equal to the fund’s current size, as part of a major commitment by the Gulf nation.
item.dc:creator: Fiona MacDonald, Dinesh Nair, Matthew Martin

media:content.media:description: Donald J. Trump in Doha on May 14. Photographer: Win McNamee/Getty Images

item.title: Hamas Says Aid Flows Must Resume After US-Israeli Hostage Freed
item.description: Hamas said it freed American-Israeli hostage Edan Alexander based on an understanding with the US that humanitarian assistance would return to Gaza and negotiations to end the war start immediately.
item.dc:creator: Sara Gharaibeh

media:content.media:description: Crowded tents in a temporary camp for displaced Palestinians in Gaza City, on Monday, May 5, 2025. Israel's security cabinet voted to intensify military operations in Gaza and call up of tens of thousands of extra reservists, while also deciding on a means of distributing aid in the Palestinian territory.

item.title: Denmark Considers Ending 40-Year Ban on Nuclear Power
item.description: Denmark is exploring adding nuclear power to its energy mix, potentially breaking away from a 40-year prohibition of the energy source, according to the Nordic country’s climate minister.
item.dc:creator: Sara Sjolin, Christian Wienberg

media:content.media:description: Lars Aagaard

item.title: Supreme Court’s Liberals Blast Trump Birthright Citizenship Plan
item.description: President Donald Trump’s executive order restricting the longstanding concept of birthright citizenship is probably illegal, the US Supreme Court’s liberal justices indicated during the first oral arguments in any of the numerous lawsuits challenging the Republican’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators outside the US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. The US Supreme Court is considering whether to allow President Donald Trumps executive order restricting the longstanding concept of birthright citizenship to start taking effect while a lawsuit proceeds.

item.title: Four in Five Canadians Believe Old US Relationship Is ‘Over,’ Poll Says
item.description: An overwhelming majority of Canadians believe the country’s relationship with the US has permanently changed, as President Donald Trump’s tariffs and sovereignty threats spark widespread fury in the northern nation.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: A "Product of Canada" sign near packaged meats at a grocery store in Langford, British Columbia, Canada, on Wednesday, Feb. 26, 2025. Furious Canadian consumers are boycotting American-made products and opting for domestic alternatives in response to US President Donald Trump's threats and actions.

item.title: GOP Tax Bill Seen Masking More Than $1 Trillion US Debt Hit
item.description: The cost of Republican lawmakers’ draft plan for sweeping tax cuts weighed in at $3.8 trillion over the next 10 years in one official estimate, a lowball projection that independent analysts say masks the true fiscal hit.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran, Nancy Cook

item.title: EU Readies New Proposals in Push to Speed Up US Trade Talks
item.description: The European Union is revising its proposals for a potential trade deal with the US as the two sides move to accelerate serious negotiations, even though the Trump administration continues to provide little clarity and make demands that negotiators see as unrealistic, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: EU Commissioner for Trade and Economic Security, Maros Sefcovic arrives at the Europa building in Brussels, on May 15.

item.title: Deadly Clashes in Libya Risk Ending OPEC-Nation’s Relative Calm
item.description: Libya’s capital has been gripped by its worst fighting in years, sparking fears the North African nation will be dragged into widespread conflict as the government cracks down on rival militias.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany

media:content.media:description: Destroyed vehicles following overnight clashes in in Tripoli, on May 13.

item.title: India Halts Turkish Airport Firm’s Operations After Pakistan Row
item.description: India stopped a Turkish company from operating at its airports after Turkey voiced support for Pakistan during a recent conflict between the two South Asian neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Taylan Bilgic, Mihir Mishra

media:content.media:description: An aircraft flies over Indira Gandhi International Airport in New Delhi, India, on Tuesday, Aug. 24, 2021. India plans to raise 6 trillion rupees ($81 billion) by leasing out state-owned infrastructure assets over the next four years to fund new capital expenditure without pressuring government finances. The proposal involves handing assets including roads, railways, airports, sports stadiums, power transmission lines and gas pipelines to private operators.

item.title: Trump Says Nothing to Happen on Ukraine Until He Meets Putin
item.description: US President Donald Trump said there’ll be no resolution of Russia’s war in Ukraine until he meets with Russian leader Vladimir Putin, as a delegation from Kyiv set off to Istanbul for potential ceasefire talks with Moscow counterparts.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Andrea Palasciano, Selcan Hacaoglu

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Medinsky Photographer: Getty Images/Getty Images

item.title: Romania’s Election Rerun: What’s at Stake as the Far Right Rises
item.description: Romanians delivered a resounding anti-establishment message in the first round of the country’s presidential election rerun, propelling hard-right leader George Simion and Bucharest’s independent centrist mayor Nicusor Dan to a high-stakes runoff to be held on May 18.
item.dc:creator: Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: The Romanian national flag in front of the parliament building in Bucharest.

item.title: Trump Targets Billions in Energy Grants for New Round of Audits
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration is deepening its review of more than $15 billion in grants and other support awarded by its predecessor for upgrading power grids and manufacturing energy technology.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Chris Wright, US secretary of energy, during a House Appropriations Subcommittee on Energy and Water Development and Related Agencies hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. The hearing is reviewing the fiscal year 2026 budget requests for the US Department of Energy.

item.title: Trump’s Rush to Cut AI Deals in Saudi Arabia and UAE Opens Rift With China Hawks
item.description: President Donald Trump’s flurry of artificial intelligence deals during his tour of the Middle East is opening a rift within his own administration as China hawks grow increasingly concerned the projects are putting US national security and economic interests at risk.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: RIYADH, SAUDI ARABIA - MAY 14: U.S. President Donald Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman speak as they arrive during the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) Leaders’ Summit at The Ritz-Carlton on May 14, 2025 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The council addresses regional stability, defense cooperation, and energy policy among Gulf nations. Trump is on a multi-nation tour of the Gulf region focused on expanding economic ties and reinforcing security cooperation with key U.S. allies. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)

item.title: Senators Revive Bill to Break Big Tech’s Grip on Pentagon Deals
item.description: A bipartisan pair of senators is reviving a bill to break the grip that tech giants like Amazon.com Inc., Microsoft Corp. and Alphabet Inc.’s Google have on the Pentagon’s cloud computing and artificial intelligence contracts.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Davalos

media:content.media:description: The Pentagon in Washington, DC.

item.title: What Is Habeas Corpus and Why Does Trump Want to Suspend It?
item.description: After a series of high-profile setbacks in federal court, the Trump administration is threatening to escalate its immigration crackdown by unilaterally suspending habeas corpus, a foundational right in the US that allows people in government custody to challenge the legality of their detention.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: ICE agents detain a suspect during a multiagency targeted enforcement operation in Lyons, Illinois.

item.title: Germany Expects €33.3 Billion Less in Taxes on Weak Economy
item.description: Germany’s federal government will reap €33.3 billion ($37.3 billion) less in tax income in the five years through 2029, as the economy’s persistently sluggish performance saps revenue.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Lars Klingbeil during a session at the Bundestag in Berlin, on May 15. Photographer: Tobias Schwarz/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: UK in Talks to Set Up Asylum Seeker Return Hubs Abroad
item.description: The UK government is in talks with several countries about hosting so-called return hubs to receive failed asylum seekers, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer seeks to reduce the cost of housing them and cut a backlog of claims that need processing.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer delivers a speech on his immigration plans on May 12. Photographer: Tolga Akmen/EPA

item.title: Republican Tax Plan Targets Clean-Energy Supplies Tied to China
item.description: A Republican tax plan seeking to cut clean-energy subsidies includes provisions that threaten to cripple the incentives before they even end.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: An employee inspects photovoltaic modules at the Longi Green Energy Technology Co. solar panel factory in Xi'an, Shaanxi Province, China, on Monday, July 20, 2020. Longi is the world's largest producer of solar wafers and the world's largest solar company by market value.

item.title: Philippine Court Voids Acquittal of Duterte Critic on Drug Case
item.description: A Philippine court has nullified an earlier decision of a lower court to acquit former Senator Leila de Lima on a drug case, a fresh setback for one of ex-President Rodrigo Duterte’s critics who just won a seat in Congress.
item.dc:creator: Manolo Serapio Jr

media:content.media:description: Leila de Lima Photographer: Jam Sta Rosa/Getty Images

item.title: Extorsiones guerrilleras limitan el desarrollo agroindustrial en los llanos colombianos
item.description: Años después del acuerdo de paz, nuevas guerrillas extorsionan a productores de palma, arroz y petróleo en Colombia. “Sin seguridad, nadie invierte”, advierte un empresario.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Bristow

media:content.media:description: In this Feb. 13, 2015 photo, a truck loaded with crude from the Campo Rubiales oil field crosses the bridge over the Manacacias River in Puerto Gaitan, Colombia. A net oil importer not too long ago, Colombia is now the fifth biggest supplier to the U.S. (AP Photo/Fernando Vergara)

item.title: EU Deal Would Give Reeves £10 Billion and Cut Risk of Tax Hikes
item.description: An improved trade deal with the European Union would hand UK Chancellor Rachel Reeves £10 billion ($13.3 billion) in the Autumn Budget and limit the need for further tax increases, according to economists.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, ahead of a news conference on the publication of the government's immigration white paper, in London, UK, on Monday, May 12, 2025. The UK will increase English-speaking requirements for migrants, and make it harder for them to stay in the country as part of efforts to rein in levels of net immigration that have touched records in recent years.

item.title: Massachusetts GOP Governor Hopeful Says DC Drama Isn’t His Fight
item.description: Brian Shortsleeve is seeking to become the next Republican governor of Massachusetts, a state that’s facing acute economic pressure from the White House’s cuts to federal funding for universities and scientific research. He doesn’t want to dwell on that.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: A Harvard University train and bus stop in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Portugal Far-Right Leader Feels Unwell During Campaign Event
item.description: Portuguese far-right Chega party leader Andre Ventura was helped away from a campaign event after feeling unwell, just days before a snap election.

item.title: EU Considers Reinstating Trade Quotas on Ukraine as War Drags On
item.description: The European Union is considering reinstating quotas on imports of several agriculture goods from Ukraine, a move that could end trade relief for the war-hit nation.

item.title: South African President to Meet Trump in Bid to Mend Ties
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa plans to hold talks with his US counterpart Donald Trump in Washington on May 21 and hopes to ease a simmering diplomatic row between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa, South Africa's president, during a news conference following a meeting with Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, at the Union Buildings in Pretoria, South Africa, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. President Volodymyr Zelenskiy became the fist leader of Ukraine to visit South Africa in a bid to expand diplomatic outreach while he can no longer fully rely on US as his nation’s key ally and the peace deal with Russia remains elusive.
